utterances: Watch the (unintelligible) in your nose, make eye contact, and just be yourself.
Okay, sounds good.
I'll remember that.
They also need to remember to smile and to rose.
Rosing is a time-honored ritual in this steeped-in-tradition town that involves lapel signs to keep out(ph) roses.
Unidentified Woman #1: They're little embroidered rose ticket.
Would you like one?
Unidentified Man #2: (Unintelligible).
Unidentified Woman #1: Okay.
I'll stick one on you, right there.
Unidentified Woman #2: There you go.
How many times have you done that before?
Unidentified Woman #2: A thousand.
Unidentified Woman #1: A thousand.
Literally, probably a step-by-step, and we probably gave out a thousand roses yesterday.
And so it will continue right up to prime day, the day Queen Mary McCluggage says...
I think you really can't put it into words what it's going to be like and you can't imagine or prepare for it at all, but I can't wait to step on that float.
My arm will get tired, I'm sure, but I'll be pumped.
Smiling and waving to the crowd, where chances are there's another little girl dreaming of the day she'll be handing out tiny roses and posing for just one more picture.
On three, 1-2-3.
Thank you.
For NPR News, I'm Gloria Hillard.
As any parent of a teenager can tell you, teens can be moody at the best of times.
So how can you tell if something more serious is actually going on?
The American Academy of Pediatrics is today releasing new guidelines aimed at flagging and treating teen depression.
NPR's Allison Aubrey reports that as many as 1 in 5 teens experience bouts of depression, but many do not get help.
It's not uncommon for teenagers to withdraw from their parents, to cut them out of communication.
And sometimes, parents don't want to pry.
Adolescent psychiatrist Rachel Zuckerbrot says this dynamic is one reason teen depression can go undetected.
So often people are suffering on the inside, but it might not be obvious on the outside.

And sometimes it gets misdiagnosed because sometimes teenagers who are depressed are actually acting out and misbehaving, and instead, they are looked at as being hostile or bad when in fact they're really suffering from depression.
Zuckerbrot says this is a problem.
She's an associate professor of clinical psychiatry at Columbia.
Most teenagers with depression don't get access to mental health care.
In fact, about 50 percent of teenagers don't even get diagnosed.
To address this, the American Academy of Pediatrics' new guidelines call for universal screening for teen depression.
What we're endorsing is that everyone who is 12 and up be given, at least once a year for their school physicals or their sports physicals, a depression screen that is a self-report questionnaire.
Was this something that was happening relatively regularly over some time?
Was it quite rare?
Well, I find out, as many of the winners I'm sure today had found out, you find out the Friday before.
You're not supposed to but apparently it leaks almost immediately.
And I had just landed, actually, in New York.
I work out of Cleveland, as you know.
My husband and I were in New York to visit one of our kids for a surprise birthday dinner.
And we had just gotten into our hotel room when my cell phone rang.
And I could see it was from the Plain Dealer but I didn't know, I didn't recognize the number.
And it was the editor, Doug Clifton, and I immediately asked what was wrong because --
You thought you were in trouble?
Well, yes.
Or at the very least I thought I hadn't won.
I asked if he had bad news for me because I had been a finalist two years before and I was quite certain I hadn't won.
And he said, well, do I have bad news?
Is it bad news to win the Pulitzer Prize?
And so, of course, I'm getting very excited.
I'm trying to talk to him.
My husband is standing in front of me saying, did you win, did you win, did you win?
So I finally nodded my head and said, yes, I won.
I'm trying to talk to Doug.
And then my husband started to cry.
So it was quite a moment.
I will never forget it.
Why was he crying?
He was so happy for me.
He was just so happy for me.

And then the day that they actually announced it, I will never forget the moment, walking into the newsroom because the newsroom found out about two hours before because once you assign a reporter to do the story that's going to run, everyone finds out.
And I didn't know everyone knew.
And I walked in and more than 300 people spontaneously gave me a standing ovation.
It was the happiest moment of my life in that newsroom.
You thought you were going to be the Susan Lucci of the Pulitzer who's always nominated and never gets the prize.
At first I had that fear, yes.
And I just didn't want to count on it.
You know, I knew how awful it felt to lose.
And I just, you know, it really seemed so far-fetched to me that I was just trying to hard not to even think about it.
Nick Anderson, did it change how you think about your work?
It made me more self-conscious and more determined to do good work consistently because I didn't want to let my guard down.
There's so much pressure on you.
And all of a sudden all these eyes are on you to see if you're going to live up to the hype.
And so to me it just, it motivated me to work harder.
That's not fun.
No.
I could make it the other way.
Why don't you just rest on your laurel?
Well, it's not the way I'm put together.
I mean, I've got 30 years left in my career.
So I figure I'm not going to rest on my laurels for 30 years.
So I used it to motivate me to do better work.
Well, Connie, you obviously didn't rest on your laurels, either.
You've got a new book coming out.

But in the immediate aftermath, did you feel -- I mean, you had a wonderful first couple of days, but after that, did you feel like you were under special pressure to be somebody other than you already were?
You do.
And you know what, there's no one that wants to hear your headache, about your headache.
Do you know what I mean?
This is not, you just can't stand back and start whining about, oh, how hard it is now that I've won the Pulitzer.
You know, it's real, Clarence Page told me recently, I ran into him, and he had won the Pulitzer several years before me for commentary.
And he said, it's really scary afterwards, isn't it?
Nobody warns you about that.
He said, we should have a support group because nobody else cares about us except those of who've won.
And, you know, I mean, literally --
You're right.
My tears are not dripping.
I'm not dipping with tears of sympathy for either of you so, you know, boo hoo.
I found out, I mean, Kate Medina, who is such a celebrated editor at Random House, called me the day after I won and said, we want to do a book of your columns.
And that would never have happened had I not won the Pulitzer Prize.
So I am very aware of the fairy dust that gets sprinkled, to quote (unintelligible), when you will win this.
And you feel, I judged five journalism contests this year.
And I did it because I felt like I had to give back because I know how these awards change your life.
Do you have a, what do you get?
Do you get a medal or plaque?
What do you get?
You get a tiny crystal, it's very pretty.
You get a parchment that you have to frame yourself.
And you get $10,000.
And you get to be called the Pulitzer Prize Winner for the rest of your life, no matter if you commit a crime, if you, no matter what you do.
That's what precedes your name.
And I think that's it.
Don't you think, Nick?
Yes, that's --
Just seconds left.
I'm sorry.
Connie, where's your parchment?
What room do you have it in?
It's in my, everything's at home.
I don't have anything in the newsroom.
It's over my desk at work.
And Nick Anderson, where's your parchment?
I have no idea.
Okay.
Nick Anderson --
